Two things to consider: First, our calendar fills up in late March, so waiting might mean we can't fit you in before the deadline. Second, if you end up owing, filing earlier doesn't mean paying earlier - you can still pay by April 15. And if you're getting a refund, you're just delaying getting your own money back. Would it help if I sent you a simple checklist of what to gather so you can collect things at your own pace?
timing_objection.reframe: Address the real concern (procrastination comfort) while highlighting practical benefits

trust_objection.objection: How do I know you won't make mistakes? / What if I get audited?
trust_objection.wrong_approach: We never make mistakes / We've never had a client audited
trust_objection.authentic_response: That's exactly the right question to ask. Here's our approach: Every return is reviewed by a [CPA/EA] before filing, and we guarantee accuracy - if there's an error on our part, we pay any penalties and interest. If you do get audited, which is rare but can happen to anyone, we provide [audit support/representation] at no additional charge. We also keep your files for [7] years in case you need anything. The IRS audit rate is about [current %], and audits usually happen because of unreported income or math errors - both things we double-check. What specific concerns do you have about your situation?
trust_objection.reframe: Acknowledge legitimate concern, provide specific protections and processes

diy_capability_objection.objection: I've always done my own taxes / I'm pretty good with numbers
diy_capability_objection.wrong_approach: You're not qualified to do this yourself

The question isn't really about capability, it's about whether the tax code complexity matches your situation. Has anything changed this year - new income sources, investments, property, life events? Even experienced DIY filers often reach out when their situation gets more complex, not because they can't do it, but because the time investment and risk of missing something becomes less appealing than it used to be. What's your situation looking like for [tax year]?
diy_capability_objection.reframe: Respect their competence while focusing on complexity and opportunity cost

relationship_objection.objection: I've used the same person/company for years

If your current preparer is doing great work, we'll tell you that. Fair enough?

complexity_denial.objection: My taxes are simple / I just have a W-2

complexity_denial.authentic_response: You might be right - if it's truly just a W-2 with standard deduction, software probably works fine. Just to make sure we're on the same page: Do you own a home, have student loans, contribute to retirement accounts, have any side income, make charitable donations, or have dependents? [If yes to any] Those actually create opportunities for optimization that might be worth a conversation. [If no to all] Honestly, you're probably fine with software. If anything changes in your situation, we're here. Can I give you my card in case your situation gets more complex next year?
complexity_denial.reframe: Qualify honestly, educate on what 'simple' really means, leave door open

retention_hooks.year_round_touchpoints: Monthly tax tip emails, quarterly 'tax health checkup' offers, keep you top of mind
retention_hooks.document_vault: Store their tax documents securely - they need you to access history, creates switching friction
retention_hooks.multi_year_comparison: Show year-over-year trends and planning - demonstrates long-term value relationship
retention_hooks.automatic_scheduling: Book next year's appointment before they leave - default to returning
retention_hooks.loyalty_pricing: Returning clients get 10% off - reward loyalty, prevent shopping around
retention_hooks.life_event_monitoring: Check in about major purchases, job changes - show proactive care
retention_hooks.referral_rewards_program: Credits accumulate - gives reason to stay engaged and return

referral_strategies.ask_at_peak_satisfaction: Request referral immediately after delivering great refund news - emotion drives action
referral_strategies.specific_ask: Don't say 'know anyone?' Say 'who else is self-employed/bought a house/started a business?'
referral_strategies.make_it_easy: Provide referral cards, email template, or unique link - remove friction
referral_strategies.double_sided_incentive: $50 credit for referrer, $25 off for new client - both parties win
referral_strategies.social_proof_campaign: Share (with permission) 'Jane referred 5 friends this year' - normalizes referring
referral_strategies.niche_targeting: Ask real estate agents for buyer referrals, ask business clients for vendor referrals - specific channels
referral_strategies.professional_partnerships: Partner with bookkeepers, financial advisors, attorneys - reciprocal referral agreements
referral_strategies.community_involvement: Sponsor local business groups, offer free workshops - become the known tax expert locally
